Valuer agreement
https://ipsentinelltd.sharepoint.com/:b:/s/IPSFingerprint/EaiPlx01gj9Nigr7qnUjbLoBO-NckNLz8x1Qh5WdFDyR9A?email=sean%40fingerprint-supervision.com&e=zf2XbJ

Interestingly, django reversion (instance versioning) works in a similar way to our elastic search approach - by serializing/deserializing objects to json: https://django-reversion.readthedocs.io/en/release-1.9.3/how-it-works.html
As it's the top package used by the django community for version control / time travel, maybe this validates the approach to store history in elastic search?
Translation not working on staging
either in email or the conversation views

Another way we could do the audit logging is via filebeat. So rather than inserting user actions into an auditlog table, we'd simply reformat our logging messages and let filebeat ingest that into elasticsearch. That data can then be read back into the API: https://www.elastic.co/blog/structured-logging-filebeat
Have added a couple of articles under Anthony Leung reporting doc in YouTrack
https://ip-sentinel.myjetbrains.com/youtrack/articles/FFE-A-18
A list of events to track.  Please review.

A few notes for django-reversion and django-rest-framework to work together:
https://ip-sentinel.myjetbrains.com/youtrack/articles/FFE-A-19/django-reversion-with-django-rest-framework
Have you used django reversion? Considering this versus simple history
Never heard of it, but I can take a look
I'm trying now in a sample project, the admin section is pretty nice and easy to configure and use, I'll check for the API implementation now
So do you think we should go with reversion or simple history?
Well, today I played with reversion and it seems pretty nice, even if it needs to create initial revisions for each model
we can also delete old revision based on what we need to keep: https://django-reversion.readthedocs.io/en/stable/commands.html
the problem is: it's enough to keep revision for each model we want, or we need to have a detailed history for models and sub-models all in one place?
good question - sub models are harder to audit
each sub model will have a reversion history on its own
but maybe we can afford that
but I'm not sure the parent model points to the specific child version
oh no, I don't think so (let me do a few more tests), I think it will keep only the versions for the base fields
for example, 1) user changes the case name and one of the case_items related model OR 2) user only changes the case name
how would you 'rewind' the case backwards?
for case 2 it's included in the history of the case, but case 1 will be included in the history of the case_item (I suppose)
what are the advantages to using django-revision do you think, as opposed to saving the object json in elasticsearch?
well, I think the output will be the same, django-revision seems to be already implemented with "time traveling" in the admin or via existent functions, but it won't work on elasticsearch models
yes, we would need to create those functions ourselves
Looking at our production database, here are the counts by action:

action    | count  

-------------+--------

 BLOCKED     |    240

 CREATE      | 271047

 HARD_DELETE |    424

 IGNORE      |   9202

 LOGIN       |  12985

 LOGOUT      |    297

 SEARCH      | 968735

 SOFT_DELETE |     39

 UNIGNORE    |      2

 UPDATE      |   1993
updates are quite small ... the biggest are create events
oh, this might be a good news
does it store an event on create?
presumably we can configure it so it only stores on change
lokking at the db now, yes, there is an "event" for each creation
sorry
format is always "json" in my db
comments and related users are stored inside reversion_revision
https://django-reversion.readthedocs.io/en/release-1.8.1/api.html
Note: If you call save() outside of the scope of a revision, a revision is NOT created. This means that you are in control of when to create revisions.
We could probably hook into that manually via the model update/delete signals (and avoid create)
Although maybe it's nice to have the first version as the current version too
yes, but in that case we can't rollback to the origina version, right?
yes
yes, as you just said
ok, well the create events are a 1:1 mapping with the object instances, so it won't blow up
and the updates are quite small
wait, why in my local project the version is "4.0.0"?
the other events (login etc) will all be in elastic search instead
oh, you're on version 4
https://django-reversion.readthedocs.io/en/stable/changelog.html
yep, no track of the "save()" problem here https://django-reversion.readthedocs.io/en/stable/api.html, maybe they solved it
oh no, the just wrote that you need to call save() inside a revision block
"You create a revision by creating a revision block. When you call save() on a registered model inside a revision block, it will be added to that revision."
but this only in custom usage, I'm using the middleware and it's storing versions automatically
my concern was for the API, but I think I found a solution for that
nice question, why not both?
could do. would probably need a 'diff' field or something in the event log
or only the instance id, then if a user wants to see the history can list all changes for that instance
yes, no luck with reversion, they store the entire object every time
current schema: https://ip-sentinel.myjetbrains.com/youtrack/articles/FFE-A-20/Event-model
I think we can probably just store the instance id
if you need to inspect their table, they are using this structure/data in reversion_version table:
If the event type is UPDATE, then we can look at history(-1)
not much readable, but I'm copy/pasting from psql commands
they are storing the model, the pk and then all fields, at every change of the record
hmm, not very efficient but simpler
if we prefer to use elasticsearch we can thake this as inspiration, maybe improving the changed fields with only the diff

I think they are storing all fields because in the admin, when you click on an history item, it will be presented with all the "old data", if you click on "save" it will be recovered at that specific state
they avoid to recreate the history back at that time
it might depends on how big is the model
Yes, we currently store only the diff in our audit log

select extra from auditing_log where action='UPDATE' limit 5;

                                                                                                                                                          extra                                                                                                                                                           

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

 {​​​​​"last_ip":["85.255.236.216","167.98.36.70"],"last_user_agent":["Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_14_4) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/73.0.3683.86 Safari/537.36","Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_14_4) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/73.0.3683.103 Safari/537.36"]}​​​​​

 {​​​​​"last_ip":["None","167.98.36.70"],"last_user_agent":["None","Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_14_0) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/73.0.3683.86 Safari/537.36"]}​​​​​

 {​​​​​"last_ip":["167.98.36.70","85.255.233.89"]}​​​​​

 {​​​​​"account":["Melqart","Valeur"]}​​​​​

 {​​​​​"fingerprint_firm":["Melqart Asset Management","Valeur"]}​​​​​
oh, that's a good point
well, better than reversion then
it would allow you to rewind multiple steps in one go
so right now it would be hard for us to rewind
because we need the id diff (of foreign keys) not the value diff
but we could change that
well, it depends also on how we would rewind the history
although it would be quite a bit more work for us to implement all the rewinding back, step by step
yes, I think so
might not be worth the time versus extra storage space needed for reversion
yes, maybe that's the case they choose that solution
I think we should try out reversion
it would offload that problem so we can move on
I'm thinking that having the latest version stored in the table, we could store the "old change" for each version, in a JS world this could be reverted using an object spread for each iteration
record_at_specific_point = { latest_version, ...version_old1, ...version_old2 }
but it will be tricky to store
yes, that's true, the iteration and update loop would be quite simple
and difficult to display
what if the user wants to see what is changed in a specific version? We will have only the "old" version for rolling back
or storing the two diffs (like red and green in git diff)
but in the end maybe the best solution could be storing the entire object
and eventually providing a diff tool to look at the differences
like they are using (if I remember correctly) with redux
comparing two object and keeping only the differences
something like this: https://github.com/dennybiasiolli/react-vuex/blob/master/src/utils/shallowEqual.js
I think it's probably simplest to store the whole objects each time. But we might want to turn off versioning for certain objects
e.g. todo items, which are read only
yes, it should be configurable on a single model, there is not a general on/off switch
maybe you can even configure the fields to track
oh, need to check on that, it will be perfect
need to try that, but we could be lucky: https://django-reversion.readthedocs.io/en/stable/admin.html

reversion_register(model, **options)

Callback used by the auto-registration machinery to register the model with django-reversion. Override this to customize how models are registered.

def reversion_register(self, model, **options):
    options["exclude"] = ("some_field",)
    super().reversion_register(model, **options)
ok cool
tomorrow I will try that on the local project, before breaking everything in the real project
things like the modified_on fields are auto changed by the system, so we can ignore those
other than this, we can keep track of models inside the django database, not on elasticsearch I think (with django-reversion)

(sorry for the italian language, it's a custom app I have locally)
It stores automatically changes to each field (need to check in the database what happens, and you can time-travel back in the admin
yes, we might as well go with that option
the question is then what to store in the UPDATE event (that is sent to the elastic search log) ... either the instance id or the history id
also, we store values, not ids
then we just choose the (user) write fields and ignore the read only fields
There is a message in from HFM... Would you please reply as I don't know the detail
